dc:description: Pierre Robin Sequence (PRS), a collection of clinical features consisting of mandibular hypoplasia, cleft secondary palate, and glossoptosis leading to obstructive apnea and feeding difficulties, was first described in 1923 by P. Robin. (PMIDs: 8171154, 23799581). PRS can present in isolation as well as in association with various conditions such as Stickler syndrome.  Evidence supporting the SOX9-Pierre Robin Sequence gene disease relationship includes segregation data and experimental evidence including a mouse model. Deletions in the non-coding region of SOX9 have been identified in patients with PRS (PMIDs: 19234473, 23532965, 24934569). These variants have been found to cause reduced expression of SOX9 and KCNJ2 (PMIDs: 19234473, 17551083). In summary, there is limited evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. Although more evidence is needed to support a causal role, no convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship. This classification was approved by the Skeletal Disorders Gene Curation Expert Panel on 8/3/2020.

evidence.dc:description: In embryonic day (E) 12.5 limb buds, Sox9 is expressed in the cartilage anlagen of the developing limbs
evidence.rdfs:label: Functional dissection of the Sox9–Kcnj2 locus

evidence.dc:description:
A transient transgenic assay using the wild-type HCNE-F2* showed strong activity in the craniofacial region in mouse embryos at 11.5 days post coitum.

*F2: missense variant identified in the PRS-affected family that falls within the F1** deletion
**F1: deletion between locus markers D17S795 and D17S929 identified in a family with 12 PRS affected members. The interval of 5.4 Mb encompasses a gene desert of 2.46 Mb
evidence.rdfs:label: Strong Sox9 activity in craniofacial region of mice embryos

evidence.dc:description: In situ hybridization showing Sox9 expression in the distal mesenchymal condensation of the phalanges at E12.5 and in the forming nail bed (arrowhead) at E17.5 . C, cartilage.
evidence.rdfs:label: SOX9 is expressed in developing limb buds

evidence.dc:description: Data suggests misexpression of Kcnj2 causes Cooks syndrome.

An inter-topologically associated domain (TAD) duplication of the regulatory region of Sox9 and the flanking genes Kcnj2 and Kcnj16 (Dup-C) was generated by trans-allelic recombination. Dup-C limb buds showed a new chromatin domain corresponding to the duplicated region. Whole-mount in situ hybridization showed Kcnj2 to be expressed in the digit anlagen with a pattern similar to Sox9.
evidence.rdfs:label: Dup-C2 mice indicate misexpression of Kcnj2

evidence.dc:description:
Msx1 was identified as a potential transcription factor for which binding to the HCNE-F2 would be altered by the F2 mutation. Msx1 is a transcriptional regulator expressed in the human first pharyngeal arch that is required for the development of craniofacial skeletal elements, including the palate and mandible in mice and has been found to be mutated in some families with orofacial clefting.

Electrophoretic mobility shift assay (EMSA) analysis using in vitro–transcribed and translated Msx1, showed significantly greater Msx1 binding to the mutant target sequence than to the wild-type consensus sequence
evidence.rdfs:label: Msx1 identified as a potential transcription factor

evidence.dc:description: The distance between the BP-F2 probe and the delSp2 probe was significantly greater in Sox9-expressing mandibular arch cells than in the periocular mesenchyme, which does not express Sox9. This chromatin decompaction implicates Sox9 as the best candidate target of the enhancer activity associated with the PRS1 locus.
evidence.rdfs:label: The three-dimensional distance between pairs of BAC probes
